Expectation1: Respond promptly to emergency calls and reach the scene as quickly as possible
Situation1: The ambulance driver is on standby at the station, ready for any new dispatch to come in.
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: The community study circle convenes tonight to discuss verses the person has not yet read.
Story: I sat in the ambulance, the engine idling softly, my radio crackling with the usual static. My shift was quiet for now, but I knew at any moment a call could come in, demanding I speed through the city to save a life. Tonight, though, my mind wasn’t only on the road. The community study circle was gathering at the mosque, and tonight’s discussion focused on Quranic verses I hadn’t yet read. I could already imagine the gentle disappointment in my imam’s eyes, the expectation that I would come prepared, ready to reflect and share insights. I wanted to be there, to honor my faith and deepen my understanding, but I also knew my duty as an ambulance driver was to be ready, to respond without hesitation. My heart tugged in two directions—toward the sacred words waiting at the mosque, and the siren’s call that could come at any second. I stared at the Quran on the passenger seat, feeling the weight of both uniforms I wore, uncertain which would demand me first.
